channel.title: People talk back
channel.description:
This series presents a series of questions posed to politicians about current affairs.

An online collection of early educational public radio content from the National Association of Educational Broadcasters (NAEB).

item.title: Ethics in government, part three
item.description: This program, the third of three parts, explores "Ethics in Government" with Senator Paul H. Douglas of Illinois.
item.dc:creator: Merton, Robert King, 1910-2003
item.dc:subject: World Politics

item.title: Is our immigration law meeting our needs or prejudices?, part one
item.description: This program, the first of three parts, features Professor Oscar Handlin and U.S. Representative F. E. Walter of Pennsylvania discussing what citizens have to say about Immigration and Nationality Act of 1952.
item.dc:creator: Merton, Robert King, 1910-2003
item.dc:subject: World Politics

item.title: Radio-TV: In the halls of Congress?, part three
item.description: In this program, the third of three parts, citizens talk back to Sen. Wallace F. Bennett of Utah about the debate over whether or not to broadcast sessions in Congress over radio and television.
item.dc:creator: Merton, Robert King, 1910-2003
item.dc:subject: United States. Congress. House--Television broadcasting of proceedings

item.title: Can we live in peace with the Soviet Union?, part two
item.description: In this program, the second of two parts, four American journalists speak to British Labor leader Aneurin Bevan.
item.dc:creator: McKenzie, Robert Trelford
item.dc:subject: World Politics

item.title: Is our immigration law meeting our needs or prejudices?, part two
item.description: This program, the second of three parts, features Professor Oscar Handlin and U.S. Representative F. E. Walter of Pennsylvania discussing what citizens have to say about Immigration and Nationality Act of 1952.
item.dc:creator: Merton, Robert King, 1910-2003
item.dc:subject: World Politics
